abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, though
            institutional development impacts are modest. Lessons for
            project preparation indicate that components which cannot be
            prepared fully, should not be included in a project, or at
            the very least, should be considered highly risky, with
            mitigation measures put into place; that broader political
            support is paramount in a country with such high political
            tensions, and where political fortunes are made, and lost
            quite fast. Hence, depending on a particular champion the
            project becomes much riskier; that participatory approaches
            involving all stakeholders from the beginning helps enhance
            ownership, providing a chance of well-implemented
            micro-projects; that it is important for learning and
            innovation loans to ensure measurable indicators early on,
            including a monitoring and evaluation system, and that staff
            are trained in data collection procedures. Lessons for
            project implementation stipulate that the Bank should not
            precede government's efforts in the area of
            decentralization because as in this case, the government did
            not fully exercise its oversight responsibility, rather led
            to tensions between the implementing agencies, and the
            government central institutions. And other lessons suggest
            that the inclusion of maintenance plans in micro-project
            proposals as a requirement, contributes to sustainability of
            the structures; that capacity building should be considered
            part of individual micro-projects, to strengthen beneficiary
            communities in project planning, and management.
